comment._content: Thanks for the note, beachcomberaustralia, it's very useful!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I am amazed at how handsome and well-proportioned this corner of Sydney was at the time.

comment.author: 84539961@N00
comment._content: Nice bit of history here, TS (the statue) is my GGG-Grandfather. This is taken on Macquarie Place looking up to the intersection of Bridge and Gresham, as TS looks west up Bridge St (closest google street view).

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: The long side of the triangle that forms Macquarie Place was the land side of buildings that sat on the original waterfront facing the mouth of the Tank Stream that widened to form Sydney Cove. Yes, all that land in Pitt Street North, Alfred Street and Circular Quay is land fill. That's why BRIDGE Street had a bridge over what was initially the most northern narrow point, and therefore crossing, of the tank stream.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Banks and Leichhardt were the first statues added to the Lands Office Bridge St facade, both on 12/2/1891 evidently. In this pic we can't see Leichhardt's niche, but presumably it would also have been vacant. See my Lands Office statue dating comments at - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5401920179/
